p:
Enhanced warming in the Arctic (north of 67°N) is seen in recent observations
1– 5 and model simulations
6– 9 with increasing greenhouse gases (GHGs), a phenomenon referred to as the Arctic amplification (AA)
1, 10 that reduces meridional temperature gradients and thus may affect midlatitude weather and climate
5, 11– 17 . Many mechanisms have been proposed to explain the AA, including a central role by sea-ice loss
2, 3, 18, 19 , reduced outgoing longwave (LW) radiation due to a stable polar temperature profile
20, 21 , increased downward LW heating due to increased water vapor and clouds
19, 22, 23 , increased poleward energy transport
23, 24 , and other processes
25– 33 . However, their relative importance is still under debate. In particular, why the largest AA occurs in the cold season (when the ice–albedo effect is small) and over areas with large sea-ice loss
3 has not been well explained by these mechanisms.
